Message.Title: The New Improved 'Slick Willy'...
Message.Msg: Willard Mitt Romney made his fortune by picking apart viable businesses, shipping American jobs to China then avoided paying taxes on the profits by utilizing complex tax evasion schemes, loopholes and offshore accounts. On top of that he has ZERO national security experience and is clueless about how to keep this country safe. This man is nothing more than another Wall Street crook and all Americans should be VERY afraid.

Mitt's quote on his taxes is that he has paid all taxes that are currently due. There is no way you can know that everything is legal with Romney returns anymore that you can say that my returns are legal. The returns may be perfectly legal. You can say that everything is legal. Mitt was probably aggressive about the decisions made to minimize tax liability. Fine. Very few people know about the Romney taxes. None of those people are posting on this message board. The Romney taxes could be clean and have no issues at all. One or more years of the Romney taxes could be in active audit by the IRS, or in some stage of dispute/resolution. The IRS will not disclose these procedures. Only Romney could release any information on problems. I would much rather Mitt stop attributing McCain quotes to Obama, than to bother with the taxes.

"I know yoo don't like the architecture - stop whining ..." got it, you don't have an answer other than integration... "thanks for updating me on ASML" You're welcome... but I've stopped posting those now...

"I know yoo don't like the architecture" IMO, their architecture is brilliant... and has been honed for 40yrs+ Anyone is a fool to try and compete in x86 space... But as strong as INtel is... They don't hold all the cards on innovation... Very soon, running windows is no longer exclusive to x86... And with the rest of the world's R&D $$ pouring into non-x86 platforms... I'm axious to find out what comes out... But I assure you, it'll be far more than just integration...!!!

"The irs seems fine with romney and so am I. You guys just dont quit but do not seem concerned about what a bad pres. obama has been." *** The stock market lost half its value under Bush and no Republican president in the last 30 years has balanced a budget. I have yet to hear a single thing that Romney would do differently. Cutting taxes doesn't create jobs and there isn't any trickle down. Exactly what's the plan??? And why is it that no Republicans seem to have any ideas on how to create jobs or fix the economy? The only idea that Republicans have is to oppose every single thing that Obama proposes. That's not a plan. Without a plan, Romney isn't going to get elected. America waits...

"And with the rest of the world's R&D $$ pouring into non-x86 platforms..." *** Yeah, all that money. That's why only Samsung has any hope of keeping up with Intel. Because of all that money that's pouring in for ARM fabrication. Not. You do know what fabless means, don't you? It means taking all the money you would spend on R&D for fabrication and keeping it. That's what the ARM shops do and that's why the fabless model is broken. It's because all that money you say is pouring in doesn't exist...
You have no idea what you are talking about. Trolling this news group for thousands of hours does not qualify you as a semiconductor industry expert. Go back to counting beans old man.

Message.Title: INTEL DOOM:IDC says European consumers are shunning ultrabooks
Message.Msg: IDC says European consumers are shunning ultrabooks IDC says European consumers are shunning ultrabooks Intel's marketing millions are not doing the trick By Lawrence Latif Fri Jul 20 2012, 15:32 INDUSTRY WATCHER IDC reports that ultrabooks are being shunned by European consumers despite Intel's marketing spending. Intel has set aside $300m to market ultrabooks that have svelt designs and promise all day battery life, two factors that should make the units popular with punters. However IDC says that consumers are shunning ultrabooks, favouring smartphones and tablets instead of buying ultrabooks that look very much like four year old Apple Macbook Air laptops. IDC wasn't very keen on ultrabooks, saying that the market is sensitive to prices - meaning that vendors will have to cut prices to tempt punters. The firm said the impending launch of Microsoft's Windows 8 will see OEMs push revamped ultrabook designs. Intel's ultrabook drive isn't all about marketing, with the firm championing with its own money the use of solid-state drives and better screens in laptops. Even with Intel's millions spent, the biggest problem is that companies such as Dell, with its impressive XPS 13 ultrabook, simply cannot undercut the equally impressive Macbook Air. Previously NPD said that ultrabooks were gaining popularity in the US premium laptop market, accounting for 15 per cent of laptops sold that cost more than $700. However it seems that IDC's European data suggests that laptop makers are not enjoying the same sort of success across the Atlantic. Âµ The Inquirer (http://s.tt/1iu2G)

Topic.Title: INTEL DOOM:IDC says European consumers are shunning ultrabooks

Message.Msg: So, have you checked out the price of that "equally impressive" Apple MacBook Air? Last I looked it was well over $1425 for the 13" model and $1800 for the 15.4" sized laptop. They do have Intel Core i7 processors and nice ram and hard drive numbers...but isn't the Dell XPS 13 much less expensive? And most of the Dell XPS Ultrabooks come with SSD drives! Talk about "British Punters..." http://shopping.yahoo.com/1012415196-macbook-pro-13-silver-notebook/specs;_ylt=AumnpH0hvY5brMDdlpsMr1AambsF

Topic.Title: INTEL DOOM:IDC says European consumers are shunning ultrabooks

Message.Msg: I always find it helpful to go upstream to understand how the posturing by the author chain. Adding the "INTEL DOOM" to the Inquirer article defines one level of negative filtering. The London based Inquirer might have a nationalistic filter that favors good news for the home town team. IDC says a number of things in their press release. The quote in question says that consumers seem to be waiting for the Intel promised price points and overall spending is slowing in Europe. Not a surprise and not unexpected. The first batches of Ultrabooks will be much more attractive to businesses for their company refereshes. The security and protection features of the Ultrabook have value to companies but not as much to consumers. "New ultra-book and ultra-slim products have come to market, but consumer spending continues to be geared toward other devices, tablets or phones, and the market remains very price sensitive or in a "wait and see" mode and therefore more receptive to lower price points for the time being. However, the Windows 8 launch in October, combined with the expected push from vendors on ultra-slim models, will help revive consumer traction and drive a rebound during the back-to-school and Christmas seasons." The original IDC article: EMEA PC Shipments Grew 9.1% in 2Q12, Supported by an Easier Year-on-Year Comparison and Vendor Push, But Demand Remained Slow, Says IDC 19 Jul 2012 LONDON, July 19, 2012 http://www.idc.com/getdoc.jsp?containerId=prUK23612312
Nice Info

Message.Title: How successful are tablets?
Message.Msg: Besides the success that iPad is seeing, how successful have tablets been so far? Whenever analysts mention the sales of tablets, the only numbers that are published are that of the iPad sales. We don't hear much if any of other tablet makers. How about the Motorola Xoom numbers, or the Samsung Galaxy tablet numbers, or the Vizio tablet sales, or any of the other tablet makers that all use ARM based processors. So are tablets successful because they are a great new alternative to the PC or is the success of the iPad alone being use to make a case for the so called cannibalization of the PC. The facts currently are that PC sales are near 400 million units a year and still expected to grow. The percentage of growth may seem small but the quantity in growth is still very large. If all the tablet sales other than the iPad grew by 100%, that would be a growth of 5 to 10 million units. But if the sales of the PC and tablets grew by a mere 5%, that would be over 20 million unit growth. So other than Apple's initial success of anything that they build, it remains to be seen if tablets are becoming an alternative to the PC. I for one do not think so. The largest and greatest chip maker, Intel, recently said that they have 20 design wins for tablets. Yet they have over 140 design wins for the Ultrabook. That fact alone seems to suggest that thin and high performance laptops may be more desireable amongst the masses than tablets. If the tablet form factor was more desireable than the desktop or the laptop, or more recently, the Ultrabook, then other tablet makers would have seen great success in sales as the iPad has seen. Tablets are very new. And the iPad is cannibalizing other tablet makers and video game makers, such as Sony and Nintendo. The iPhone has caused most damage against other smartphone makers such as Rimm or Nokia. I could verifiably say that the iPhone did not cannibalize laptop sales and can confidently say that the iPad will not cannibalize laptops as well.
The IPad was pitched as the internet in your hands. Don't think tablets cannibalize PCs because PCs are for general purpose computing and tablets have a much more narrow scope.

Intel is a great investment for dividends and many other reasons. China slow-down is not that bad and a lot of stats show recovery. Corporations continue to make money but Wall Street ignores the real results. 71 percent beat. Black and white...

Message.Title: 40% of TSMC's revenue is generated by processes at least ten years old
Message.Msg: TSMC Predicts Slumping Sales Through 2012 "The interesting thing about these breakdowns is that it shows how slowly most companies move from node to node. Intel, AMD, Qualcomm, and Nvidia are the exceptions, not that rule. Although this chart is a revenue breakdown rather than a per-unit sales analysis, 40% of TSMC's revenue is generated by processes at least ten years old. Toss in 65nm, which debuted in 2006, and 65% of the company's sales by revenue are in what the PC world thinks of as "old tech." http://hothardware.com/News/TSMC-Predicts-Slumping-Sales-Through-2012-May-Dedicate-Whole-Fabs-To-Customers/ [An illustration of how far away TSMC is from the cutting edge. They are still selling more 90nm processors than 28nm processors...]
